linkTarget.anchoringText: According to formula (3), we can generate initial channel centerline which is composed of a lot of control points equally spaced (Fig.1). From the bank retreat equation, the positions of control points d each migration computation can be determined. These simulated points are linked together using cubic spline function to get the simulated channel centerline at each simulation stages. As shown in Fig.1, the centreline 1 was transformed to centerline 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Computation method of meander migration simulation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Computation method of meander migration simulation

linkTarget.anchoringText: The comparison between simulated centerlines and observed channel centerline in satellite picture shows very small differences(Fig.2). The simulated centerlines have more smooth geometry. The geometry of meandering river is well reproduced.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Comparison between practical meandering river and simulated centerlines

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison between practical meandering river and simulated centerlines

linkTarget.anchoringText: Firstly, we generate a lot of initial channel centerlines based on Formula 3(Fig.3).

Then the meander migration simulation was implemented to get the simulated centerlines at each stage. The final centerline and initial centerline of each channel were extracted from simulated realizations(Fig.4).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Simulated channel centerlines and separate point bars

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simulated channel centerlines and separate point bars

linkTarget.anchoringText: As shown in Fig. 5, the compound meander belt model consists of 4 zones. The bottom surface of zone 2 with grid lines was shown. The plan extent of zone 2 was divided into 2 areas, the simulation area which indicate the channel belt and un-simulation area which indicate inter channel deposits or flood plain. The large scale facies distribution in plane can be determined easily according to limited well logs and seismic attribute study. For example, the maximum amplitude attribute can be used to determine the lateral geometry of meander belt.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Meander belt model and structured gridded surface

formatted-caption.caption-text: Meander belt model and structured gridded surface

linkTarget.anchoringText: Meander loop will be extracted stochastically from database and sequentially placed in the simulation zone. As shown in Fig. 6, a meander loop was selected stochastically from database. A control point in the outer boundary of meander loop was chosen as simulation point.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: The simulation process of a meander loop

formatted-caption.caption-text: The simulation process of a meander loop

linkTarget.anchoringText: The point bar model is a surface model. The top surface of single point bar is consistent with top horizon of meander belt model and its horizontal boundary is the same as envelop of meander loop. The bottom surface of single point bar is consistent with bottom horizon of meander belt and its boundary is the enlarged version of meander loop (Fig.7). The original envelop of meander loop will expand outward half width of a channel.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Construction of surface model of point bar

formatted-caption.caption-text: Construction of surface model of point bar

linkTarget.anchoringText: The reservoir is in the Minghuazhen formation at an average depth of 1100m. The vertical reservoir profile is composed of 2-3 fining up cycles. Each cycle corresponds to a single meander belt. Each meander belt is formed due to long term migration, swing and repeatedly cutoff of multiple meandering rivers. The internal architecture of each meander belt becomes more complicated with lateral division of abandoned channels(Fig.8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Internal architecture pattern of NmI3 compound channel belt

formatted-caption.caption-text: Internal architecture pattern of NmI3 compound channel belt

linkTarget.anchoringText: The M oilfield was put into production in May 28, 2002, start with vertical wells, nine spot injection pattern, well spacing of 300-400m. The basic well positions were designed through seismic attribute study, which can approximately describe the horizontal distribution of compound channel belt (Fig.9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Maximum amplitude attribute of NmI3 interval

formatted-caption.caption-text: Maximum amplitude attribute of NmI3 interval

linkTarget.anchoringText: After more than 10 years of water-flooding development, NmI3 interval has entered into the high water-cut stage with low production rate. The production dynamic response becomes more and more complex(Fig.10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Pie chart of water cut rate and production rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pie chart of water cut rate and production rate

linkTarget.anchoringText: How to design horizontal wells to restore the production rate is the most important thing. 90°phase seismic data can recognize the envelope of compound sand body, but hard to recognize single sand body(Fig.11).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: 90 ° phase seismic data can’t recognize single channel sand body

formatted-caption.caption-text: 90 ° phase seismic data can’t recognize single channel sand body

linkTarget.anchoringText: Firstly, we need to characterize the single channel belt and construct the compound channel belt model. Because the tops and bases of the channel belts can not be resolved independently from the seismic data, their horizontal extent can be determined. An inter well 3D correlation technique was used to characterize the channel distribution and internal structure of compound meander belt. As shown in Fig.12, the NmI3 zone was subdivided into 2 to 3 sub-zones, the reservoir architecture was well reproduced.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: 3D inter well correlation result of part of NmI3 compound sand body

formatted-caption.caption-text: 3D inter well correlation result of part of NmI3 compound sand body

linkTarget.anchoringText: Firstly, a geometry database of meander loop was built. The regular well pattern provides abundant conditioning data which control the placement of meander loop. As shown in Fig.13, the vertical position of point bar was controlled by the horizon model and the outer boundary of point bar was well conditioned to the contacting position of different channels.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Facies controlling modeling of point bar

formatted-caption.caption-text: Facies controlling modeling of point bar

linkTarget.anchoringText: All the realizations were input to the simulator to conduct history matching. The ultimate goal is to find a reservoir model that adequately reproduces the past performance of the reservoir under given conditions. The optimal model is presented in Fig.14.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Modeling result of meander belt of NmI3 interval

formatted-caption.caption-text: Modeling result of meander belt of NmI3 interval

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Design of well position based on point bar model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Design of well position based on point bar model

linkTarget.anchoringText: The production history curve of Well I3H was shown in Fig.16. The initial production rate is about 80 m3 per day and keep a stable value of 40 m3 per day.
